awd_titl_txt: Unlocking the hard tissue record of primate adaptability to environmental change
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern humans have been able adapt to a diverse range of natural environments, and non-human primates can provide relevant models for understanding the evolutionary origins of this adaptive versatility in humans. This project will investigate variability in growth patterns and diet in response to early life environments, using climate, behavioral, and skeletal data for savanna baboons. The research will advance knowledge about relationships between life history flexibility and environmental variability in the human and non-human primate evolutionary record. The project also will support broader participation of underrepresented groups in STEM research, student mentoring and training, and public engagement through Smithsonian Institution programs and exhibits. Infrastructure for research and education will be enhanced by establishing the first available skeletal collection representing primates from a well-documented savannah habitat, thought to have been an important environment shaping early human adaptation. Results from the study will be communicated online, and to local wildlife managers.  

Key questions in biological anthropology concern the role that environmental variability played in shaping modern human behavior and life history, which increases fertility and maximizes offspring investment over a prolonged juvenile dependency. Developmental plasticity, including the capacity to respond to environmental change through shifts in growth rates, maturational timing, and other traits, is a proposed mechanism underlying the modern human life history strategy. However, the evolutionary origins and ecological context of life history flexibility in the human lineage remain poorly understood. This project integrates long-term climate data with developmental, behavioral and ecological data in wild baboons from a single, highly dynamic environment in the Amboseli basin, Kenya, to test how early life physical and social/maternal environments influence (1) hard tissue microanatomical parameters of dental and body size development, and (2) tooth carbon and nitrogen stable isotope signatures of diet quality and composition. Specifically, this research investigates whether offspring born into low rainfall and poor maternal/social environments experience negative consequences that are detectable in hard tissues, including lower quality diets, reduced investment in physical growth, and increased susceptibility to later-life stress.  Elucidating how early environmental challenges in Amboseli baboons are mediated by developmental and behavioral mechanisms will improve understanding of this species' resilience despite significant environmental change.  Further, by contributing a framework for deciphering the proximate ecological context of life history variation in hard tissues, this research has transformative potential for investigating relationships between adaptive versatility and environmental change during human evolution.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A key challenge in biological anthropology is understanding the relationship between ecological variability and human evolutionary history, including the role that environmental fluctuations in eastern Africa played in shaping the unique life history strategies and flexibility of modern humans. As modern humans, we are known for our exceptional ability to adapt physiologically to our diverse surroundings, mediated in part by variation in body size growth, maturational timing, fertility, and other traits. However, many questions remain about the evolutionary origins of this unique life history flexibility in the human lineage. One promising approach to addressing these questions leverages modern primate skeletal biology and dietary ecology to contextualize similar patterns obtained from the fossil remains of our hominin ancestors. The main objective of this project was to examine how variation in life history and its environmental context can be detected in the skeletal tissue record of a contemporary primate population.      

Given parallels in habitat preferences and behavioral flexibility, the long-term study population of yellow baboons from the Amboseli Basin of southern Kenya provides a salient model for understanding life history versatility in the human lineage. We had two major aims. First, we aimed to recover naturally accumulated skeletons of Amboseli baboons, most of which represent individuals with associated behavioral, demographic and other datasets collected in life by the Amboseli Baboon Research Project, to be curated as a scientific resource by the National Museums of Kenya, Nairobi. In parallel, we aimed to conduct monthly sampling of key baboon plant foods from the Amboseli landscape to capture seasonal isotopic variation in vegetation as a means of contextualizing isotopic variability in baboon diet (as reflected by stable carbon and nitrogen isotope values measured from dental tissues). Second, we aimed to integrate long-term climate records and behavioral data collected from individual baboons in life with novel anatomical and stable isotope proxies of life history and dietary ecology to test how variation in baboon early life physical and social/maternal environments are manifested in skeletal tissues.

We have made significant progress on completing our first aim. However, analyses of baboon skeletal and plant food samples in fulfillment of our second aim is ongoing, having been substantially delayed during the COVID 19 pandemic and a restructuring of the Kenyan wildlife research permitting system.  Nonetheless, these samples, both skeletal and plant, provide one of the most spatially and temporally resolved natural history collections in eastern Africa relevant to interpreting the ecological drivers of human adaptability in the fossil record.   

This project has had significant broader impacts on numerous fronts. First, it has significantly enhanced resources and infrastructure to support scientific research in Kenya. The Amboseli baboon skeletal collection currently represents 85 individuals, and infrastructure enhancements have been made to support its long term curation by the National Museums of Kenya in Nairobi as a scientific and training resource. To our knowledge this is the first collection of its kind from savannah dwelling primates that provides opportunities to integrate long term behavioral, ecological, life history, climatological and skeletal datasets. Combined with over 1,200 monthly baboon plant food samples also collected from the Amboseli basin, these resources enable researchers interested in the paleobiology of our human ancestors to ground-truth inferences associated with paleoecological proxies that are frequently limited to ancient contexts (e.g., stable isotope data from hominin enamel). This project has also fostered new collaborations between U.S. and Kenyan academic institutions, museums and wildlife management authorities in support of the above two aims, and enhanced research and training opportunities for students and scientists in both countries. Three undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral scientist in the U.S.A., and three students and post-graduates in Kenya, have learned and participated in skeletal collections recovery and curation, plant identification and accessioning, and/or methods for skeletal tissue histology, microscopy and analysis; two U.S. students from underrepresented backgrounds are also undertaking independent research utilizing resources generated from this project. The scientific collections (skeletal and plant samples) generated by this project will continue to enhance opportunities for research led by Kenyan, U.S. and other international scientists that seek to understand the ecology of modern primates in eastern Africa as well as the paleobiology of our hominin ancestors.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2023
Modified by: Shannon Mcfarlin
